
<!DOCTYPE html>

  <link rel="stylesheet" href="https://github.com/masonpidlaski/fcc-tribute/edit/main/README.md/styles.css">
<meta charset="UTF-8">

<main id="main">
<h1 id="title">
   Albert Camus
    </h1>
    <h2>
      <i>A Pioneer of Absurdist Philosophy</i>
      </h2>
    <div class="center" id="img-div">
    <img id="image" src="data:image/jpeg;base64,"
    </div>
    <figcaption id="img-caption">Camus, 1913-1960, served as a prominent French communist journalist throughout the Second World War
        </figcaption>
      <ul id="tribute-info">
        <li>November 7th, 1913, born in the occupied French Algeria, grew up lacking several basic material posessions in the poverty stricken country</li>
        <li>1924, Camus gained a scholarship to a lyceum in Algiers, and later was strongly influenced in his works through studying the philosophies of Nietzshe and the Ancient Greeks </li>
        <li>1935, Camus joined the French Communist Party, as he was a strong advocate for anti-colonialism, anti-facism. Throughout his time in government, he gained mistrust for bureacrocies that priotized efficiency over justice, which sharpened his views on human dignity and the Absurd</li>
        <li>He left the FCP a year later, and in 1938 joined the French leftist journal Alger Republicain.</li>
        <li>1940, Alger Republicain was banned in France, and Camus took a role as editor-in-chief at Paris-Soir. </li>
        <li>While in Paris, Camus published some of his most highly regarded works, <i>L'Etranger</i>, a novel, and <i>The Myth of Sisyphus</i>, an essay
        <li>After spending many years as a journalist and author, Camus would go on to teach across many universities in Europe and the Americas. He won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1957, the second youngest winner at that time (age 44)
          <li>January 4th, 1960, Camus suddenly dies in a car crash. His Final work, Le Premier Homme, was found unfinished, with only 144 pages of the handwritten novel being completed. Camus explained the was to be his finest work, based on his upbringing in French Algeria
        </ul>
        <p>If you'd like to read more on the life and works of Albert Camus, check out his Wikepedia <a id="tribute-link" target="_blank" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albert_Camus">here</a></p>
  </main>
  </html>
